query: I receive Attendance Allowance but my care needs have increased in Cambridgeshire. Can the council provide additional financial support?

retrieved_documents.content:
[Page 2 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]
 
 
2 | Cambridgeshire County Council –  Paying for care - Easy Read | April  2025  
 Pictures  Words  
 Eligible  for care and support  means that we have 
looked at your needs and agree that you need 
support.  
 A Financial Assessment  is when the council looks 
at how much money you have.  
 
This is to see if you need to pay for your care and 
support.  
 The government says if you have more than £23,250 
in savings and assets , then you need to pay for the 
full cost of your care and support . 
 If you have less than £23,250  in savings and assets, 
then the council may pay some money towards the cost of your care and support.

[Page 2 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]

 Pictures  Words

6 | Cambridgeshire County Council –  What happens if you need care and support when you leave 
hospital ? | August  2024  
 Can I get any financial help from the NHS?  
In some circumstances, people with long- term complex health needs 
may qualify for care funded by the NHS. This is called NHS Continuing 
Healthcare funding. You can find out more information by looking at 
www.nhs.uk and searching ‘NHS Continuing Healthcare’ .  
 
To find out more:   
Cambridgeshire County Council  
 
Telephone: 0345 045 5202  
 
Email: careinfo@cambridgeshire.gov.uk  
 
Website: www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/residents/adults

[Page 6 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]
 
6 | Cambridgeshire County Council –  What happens if you need care and support when you leave 
hospital ? | August  2024  
 Can I get any financial help from the NHS?  
In some circumstances, people with long- term complex health needs 
may qualify for care funded by the NHS. This is called NHS Continuing 
Healthcare funding. You can find out more information by looking at 
www.nhs.uk and searching ‘NHS Continuing Healthcare’ .  
 
To find out more:   
Cambridgeshire County Council  
 
Telephone: 0345 045 5202  
 
Email: careinfo@cambridgeshire.gov.uk  
 
Website: www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/residents/adults

. This is called a Direct Payment. Am I eligible? Direct Payments are available to people who qualify for support from us and who are either: aged 16 or over with a physical disability, learning disability, visual impairment, HIV Aids, mental health issues, or within the Autistic spectrum people over 65 parent/carers of disabled children (find out more about Direct Payments for children in Cambridgeshire ) We will carry out an assessment , then find out what you want to achieve. We will then look with you at the ways your needs could be best supported. This will be written down in a document called a support plan . We will allocate you a level of budget that is calculated be enough to meet your level of needs, this is referred to as a Personal Budget. Your Personal Budget will be made up of the amount we financially assess you as being able to cover yourself plus any contribution the Council might make

[Page 2 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]
   
 
2 | Cambridgeshire County Council – Paying for care  | April  2025 
 If you are assessed as needing to pay for your care and support, you will 
need to start putting money aside for when you receive invoices from the 
council.   Some types of income, such as money from certain disability  
benefits and pensions, and certain types of capital, may not be counted in the Financial Assessment.  This will be explained further at your 
Financial Assessment.  
Full details of how we work out how much you will pay are in the 
Adult 
Social Care Charging Policy (PDF 238KB) . 
After your assessment we will send you a letter to explain the result.  
If you are  eligible for financial assistance to pay for care and support, the 
council can arrange services for you. Alternatively, you can choose to 
receive Direct Payments  and arrange the services yourself.   You can 
find out more about Direct Payments on page 6 . 
Paying for care in your own  home

[Page 2 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]

 If you are assessed as needing to pay for your care and support, you will 
need to start putting money aside for when you receive invoices from the 
council.   Some types of income, such as money from certain disability

Full details of how we work out how much you will pay are in the 
Adult 
Social Care Charging Policy (PDF 238KB) . 
After your assessment we will send you a letter to explain the result.  
If you are  eligible for financial assistance to pay for care and support, the

find out more about Direct Payments on page 6 .

Financial support from the NHS  
Pictures  Words

  This is money that comes from the NHS to pay for your care and support. You must meet certain requirements to get this money.

4 | Cambridgeshire County Council – Find out if you can get help from ASC  - Easy Read | July  2024 
 Pictures  Words  
 
 
 To get help from the council you need to meet 
something called Eligibility Criteria. 
Eligibility Criteria  are a set of rules that the council 
uses to check if you can have council support.  
 To be able to get help from the council the Care Act 
2014  says you must have a physical or mental 
impairment or illness.  
The Care Act 2014 considers a learning disability as 
a ‘mental impairment’.  
 If you want to arrange and pay for your care and 
support yourself, you do not need to talk to the council.  
But the council m ay still be able to help you get the 
best price for your care and support.  
 If you have more than £23,250, you will have to pay 
for your care and support yourself.  
 This is called being a self-funder .

 Pictures  Words  
 
 
 To get help from the council you need to meet 
something called Eligibility Criteria. 
Eligibility Criteria  are a set of rules that the council 
uses to check if you can have council support.

2014  says you must have a physical or mental 
impairment or illness.

a ‘mental impairment’.

support yourself, you do not need to talk to the council.

answer:
If your care needs have increased in Cambridgeshire, the council may be able to provide additional financial support, depending on your financial situation and eligibility. 

- **Eligibility for Council Support**: You must meet the eligibility criteria set by the council, which involves having a physical or mental impairment or illness as per the Care Act 2014. A financial assessment will determine if you qualify for additional support based on your savings and assets.

- **Financial Assessment**: If you have less than **£23,250** in savings and assets, the council may contribute towards your care costs. If you have more, you will likely need to pay the full cost yourself.

- **Direct Payments**: If eligible, you can receive Direct Payments to arrange your care services yourself. This will be based on a personal budget that considers your assessed contribution and any council contribution.

- **NHS Continuing Healthcare**: If you have long-term complex health needs, you might qualify for NHS Continuing Healthcare, which is funding provided by the NHS for care and support.

**Next Steps**:
- Contact Cambridgeshire County Council for a financial assessment and to discuss your increased care needs. You can reach them at **0345 045 5202** or via email at **careinfo@cambridgeshire.gov.uk**.
- For more information on NHS Continuing Healthcare, visit [www.nhs.uk](https://www.nhs.uk) and search for ‘NHS Continuing Healthcare’. 

According to the documents, these are the available options and steps you can take to seek additional support.

test_metadata.prompt_template:
Please answer the following question about social care services in UK local authorities based only on the information in the provided documents.

Question: {query}

Context from relevant documents:
{context}

Instructions:
1. Provide a clear, direct answer that would help someone needing this information. If information isn't available, state: "The available documents don't provide specific information about [aspect]."

2. Synthesize information from ALL relevant documents to provide the most complete answer rather than analyzing documents individually.

3. Structure your response with:
   - A concise 1-2 sentence summary first
   - Relevant details organized in short, clear paragraphs
   - Bullet points for lists or step-by-step information
   - Bold text for key information the user should notice

4. For financial information:
   - Include exact figures, time periods, and what the funding covers
   - Present financial data clearly: "The adult social care budget is **£X million** for [time period]"

5. Always include practical next steps or resources:
   - Provide contact information, URLs, or application methods mentioned in the documents
   - Suggest where the person could find more information

6. When citing sources, use a simple format: "According to [document name/description]" or include URLs where available.

Answer:
